ANSWER: Based on the diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma, I recommend a comprehensive treatment approach that combines evidence-based medical management with patient-centered care strategies. The treatment plan includes surgical excision or Mohs micrographic surgery to ensure complete removal of the lesion with minimal tissue loss, particularly given its facial location. This is supported by clinical guidelines emphasizing high cure rates and optimal cosmetic outcomes for facial BCCs.
Initial management focuses on confirming the diagnosis through dermoscopy and biopsy if not already performed. Once confirmed, surgical removal will be scheduled, with preoperative counseling about the procedure, potential risks, and expected cosmetic results. For superficial or low-risk lesions, topical treatments like imiquimod may be considered as adjuncts or alternatives, especially if surgery is contraindicated.
Follow-up care will include scheduled skin examinations every 6-12 months to monitor for recurrence or new lesions, emphasizing patient vigilance. Education will cover skin protection strategies, including sun avoidance and the use of broad-spectrum sunscreens, to reduce future risk.
Immediate actions (today): Arrange for biopsy if not completed; inform patient about the potential diagnosis and plan; provide educational materials about BCC.
Short-term goals (1-4 weeks): Schedule surgical intervention; educate the patient on the procedure; ensure understanding of postoperative care.
Long-term objectives (3-6 months): Achieve complete lesion removal; monitor for recurrence; reinforce sun safety behaviors; assess for any new or changing skin lesions.
Patient handout summary: The plan involves removing the cancerous skin lesion safely, protecting your skin from sun damage, and scheduling regular follow-up exams to keep your skin healthy in the future.
